captions.text: If you want to be a really good road rider, then one of the essential techniques you're going to need to learn is how to perform a track stand
well at least it is if you want to look cool infront of the kids
firstly you need to find a gradual uphill stretch of road
roll slowly along it bringing yourself to a hault either through using your brakes
or simply the gradient. Make sure that you're stood out of the saddle with your arms reasonably straight
as the bike comes to a stop put your front wheel at a slight angle
line your pedals up straight or horizontal so three and nine o'clock
I don't always do this but a good tip is to look ahead of you towards the horizon
as you come to a complete stop you're going to need to angle your front wheel slightly against the gradient
whether that be to your left or to your right
if you do feel like you're about to lose your balance or completely topple over
then simply pedal away
and try again rather than putting your foot on the ground
as you grow in confidence you'll need
to resist that feeling of falling off
by placing your front wheel at an angle
facing up hill, the gradient will create
a resistance as you rock forwards and backwards on your balance point
this is tricky to master but you can do it by distributing the weight from your left to right pedals
just small amounts
than use your upper body to counterbalance the motion. Why bother?
well being able to track stand is particularly useful if you live in an urban area with lots of
traffic lights
it'll mean that you don't have to continually unclip and then re clip back into your pedals
it'll also give you increased balance and general overall control of your bike
For more of this kind of thing
Subscribe Now

title: How To Track Stand Like a Pro

comments.author: Global Cycling Network

comments.text:
I wonder if somebody has thought about this, but I found it's possible to 
trackstand on a level surface using your front brake. That is - by locking 
your front brake ant pushing with your hands forwards you build momentum 
with your body mass. Then release the brake and start moving backwards. 
Forward movement is a usual push on pedals.﻿
comments.author: Karolis Dovidavičius

Rocco

comments.author: Kyle Broflovski

comments.text:
Had to check this vid just to see what a track stand was; pleased to find 
out I've already mastered that one under the guise of 'keeping my balance 
for as long as possible at lights, junctions & busy roundabouts'! I've yet 
to clip my foot into the world of clipless, but I just saw it as an 
opportunity to test my bike handling skills & finer balance control. I 
wasn't aware it was recommended to do it on slight inclines or to have the 
front wheel turned towards/away from your lead foot. I just stood on 
horizontal pedals (I find finer control/maneuverability esp at low speed 
easier if you're out of the seat), teasing them back and forth as necessary 
and if it was a long pause or I felt my balance go then a quick flick of 
the handlebars (in either direction) would suffice. Staying in a gear one 
heavier than you'd normally stop with meant greater resistance and a more 
powerful pull away once it was green/flashing amber & clear.﻿

comments.text:
I learned to trackstand years ago when I was living in the UK.  However, 
the camber of the roads and riding on the left meant that I only mastered 
the technique when the slope rises to the right, i.e. with my front wheel 
pointing uphill to the right.  Now I live in France and, despite my best 
efforts, I just can't get the hang of trackstanding with my wheel pointing 
left and uphill.  I've tried mirroring my movements including which pedal 
is forward but it just feels to unnatural.  Any tips on how to get over 
this problem?﻿

comments.author: Isaiah 53

comments.text:
I'm not saying completely lug the motor while applying full brake.  This is 
part of basic riding skills and learning how to feather the clutch and slow 
speed maneuver.  Very useful in stop and go traffic (unless you like 
picking up and putting your foot down every 2 seconds).  This technique is 
taught in most beginner motorcycle classes in the US.  Not very fuel 
consuming at all.  ( I should know, I commute on my motorcycle in NYC)
comments.author: Chris Davieds

comments.text: Thanks! But it seems like highly fuel consumption.. :(
comments.author: Isaiah 53

comments.text:
Yes.  Not quite like on a bicycle just because of the weight, but what you 
do is ride the rear brake and at the same time feather the clutch and 
throttle.  What you want to do is basically build up some drivetrain 
resistance.  Look up "motorcycle slow race"
comments.author: Chris Davieds

comments.text:
I did a cyclocross race a few weeks ago and now I'm using that same 
mountain bike for a commuter. What works great for me (on reasonably flat 
or downhill sections of road) is to start on the right side of the bike, 
set my right foot on the pedal in the 2 o clock position, then press down 
and swing my left leg over as the bike starts moving. I use chep platform 
pedals currently though so I'm not sure how it works with clipless. I'll 
tell you this though, it makes you feel cool :P

comments.author: adam tetzlaff

comments.text:
started trackstands on a fixed gear, then tried them on my road. after 
doing a lot of them on both i find it's much easier on the road bike (given 
the slightest incline). on fixed gear you have to worry about your pressure 
distribution on both pedals since each foot changes the movement of the 
bike in a different direction. on the freewheel road bike you only have to 
worry about one foot and only countering that incline, plus there's a more 
relaxed geometry.

comments.text:

comments.author: Ted Ferenczy

comments.text:
That's true, but my feeling is that a "true" track stand is done on a track 
bike; ie a fixie. That way you can pedal both forwards and backwards in 
order to keep your balance. A 2 wheel vehicle is always steered by first 
leaning, then steering in the same direction to "catch" your center of 
gravity. In the video, the rider steers Left and pedals forward (Left) to 
catch himself when his center of gravity is Left; he allows the bike to 
roll back and to the Right when his COG is to the Right
comments.author: Ted Ferenczy

comments.text:
I think you can be partially right about that... but then I took into 
account how trials riders/mountain bikers do trackstands while picking 
lines.
comments.author: Patrick Li

comments.text:
I think track stands are only truly possible on a fixed-gear bicycle. Being 
able to move the bike backwards by pedaling backwards is very helpful. 
That's why he teaches it on a gradient; so that your free-wheel-hub bicycle 
will naturally roll backwards when stopped. A good rider can balance pretty 
well on a flat at a red light even with a free-hub bike, but as you can see 
at the end of the video, the rider edged forward once or twice to keep his 
balance before the light turned and he rode off.
comments.author: Ted Ferenczy

comments.author: Catcrumbs

comments.text:
There is a good exercise to start with. Try a low rate in a sitting 
position to make as more turn. Almost 90 degrees. At some point you have to 
stop and then can best be felt balance. After working out for an hour or 
two, you stand up and you will immediately feel that right is far easier. 
After two more hours of training will be able to stand more than a minute.
comments.author: dian2n

comments.text:
You need to learn this first with normal pedals, where you can put your 
foot down to ground fast in case you need to. When you have learned and 
practiced it enough (for like 2-3 months), change pedals and set the pedal 
tension to very low and try it in traffic free area. Check my video too i 
explain how I learned it myself watch?v=BgAUs0QGDII
